text: Janet Evanovich is a phenomenon in
American publishing she's a mystery
writer the author of the Stephanie plum
series and every book in it
seems to debut at number one and our
bestseller list Janet Evanovich visited
The Times recently and we talked about
her books and about the many family she
manages the cast of characters in her
novels which she thinks of as a family
the actual literal family who supervised
her growing franchise and the family she
seems closest to evolved the huge
legions of fans who come to every
reading and gobble up each book as its
published Janet Evanovich welcome thank
you you're 15 Stephanie plum novels been
published as always number one New York
Times bestseller how do you manage
what's become a massive franchise how do
you remain a writer on the one hand and
someone who really patrols a universe of
characters and readers well I have a lot
of help we're a little family business
my son is my agent and he's takes care
of all of the contracts and a lot of the
financial things that go on and my
daughter is my webmaster
both of them help to edit the books I
have a great family and what they really
do is they allow me to write the book
and then they do everything else around
me your novels in a sense are really
about families - they're really - family
Stephanie has one famous grandmother
Mazur and then also the family of people
she works with and what you've done it
seems to me is taken the the mystery
genre and made it more about values and
and family life and in your book how I
write you talk about the values you try
to impart in those books and what are
they I think family is important I think
that community is important I think you
know we're not little islands I grew up
in a little town everybody knew
everybody we all took care of each other
but every created that world I think it
still exists all over this country in
pockets I I feel like I have the
community I have the support system the
readers the booksellers the publishers
all of those people we all get together
this is all you know a community effort
this business about writing and
producing and selling and reading and
enjoying a book in fact your readers
through the website are actually
involved to some extent in the books
you're right and what do they do exam
well they pick the title for about 10
years now we've had a title contest
every summer it's going on now and
because it turns out I suck at titles
now you did not begin as a mystery
writer you wrote category romances yeah
and why did you switch I sort of was
kicked out I Black was never the world's
best romance writer and I I got halfway
through that career and I realized that
I I always had a little mystery in there
and my editors were always pulling the
mystery out and finally I said to myself
you know this isn't exactly where I need
to be I need to move over into crime
fiction so did you have to teach
yourself how to be a crime writer yeah
how do you do it I did a lot of reading
I found that I loved Robert B Parker and
that his books
I liked him because he wrote linear
books easy to read no flashbacks he's a
absolute word Smith I liked that he had
good people that is his hero was you
know his own person so I used him as you
know sort of as a model for myself and I
said you know I think I can take what I
love about romance which is the very
positive characters I was writing with a
lot of humor
the sexual adventure the chase and I can
move that into a mystery format and kind
of make a hybrid squash it all together
and do you consider that your innovation
as a writer blending those two forms I
don't know if I would go so far as to
say innovation that that's you know
pretty lofty language you know Sue
Grafton and Sara Paretsky and a lot of
other ladies brought women to the
forefront in the mystery genre but they
were pretty much hard-boiled and I
think that if I innovated anything it
was bringing the soft-boiled woman in
you know because Stephanie plum
you know she's got Jersey hair and she
cares about her manicure and she's not
great at what she does but she's very
tenacious and she's a little lucky and
she gets help from all kinds of people
and so yeah I think I did I did some
things that were new you've also said
that you and your readers are all kind
of growing up together with your series
where do you feel you are now with this
hugely best-selling series you're
probably the most popular mystery writer
alive you have this very famous
character every single book is a number
one bestseller do you ever think maybe
at some point you'll want to go in
another direction are you very happy
with Stephanie and all the new books to
come oh I like this description I think
that I have lots of places to go I love
writing Stephanie I do have a new series
succumbing that came out of the plum
series I have a new character diesel
next year in 2010 we're moving that
we're bringing him out at the end of the
summer and we're giving him a new lady
he's gonna have a new heroine her name
is Izzy and it's fun and that's the book
I'm writing now so I and I just I love
that I love the beginnings of this you
know this new series you hear often from
your readers you meet them all the time
sometimes thousands at a time is there
any way to characterize them I would
characterize them by saying they are
fabulous I have the world's best readers
they are good people they come to my
signings they bond with each other
they're good humoured maybe it reflects
the books somewhat because I write happy
books about good people and and this is
that's who my readers are Thank You
Janet Evanovich thank you
